trans-unit.source: Working with the Mobile Services managed client library (Windows | Xamarin) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Working with the Mobile Services managed client library (Windows | Xamarin) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use a .NET client for Azure Mobile Services with Windows and Xamarin apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use a .NET client for Azure Mobile Services with Windows and Xamarin apps.

trans-unit.source: How to use the managed client library for Azure Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: How to use the managed client library for Azure Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the managed client library for Azure Mobile Services in Windows and Xamarin apps.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the managed client library for Azure Mobile Services in Windows and Xamarin apps.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include querying for data, inserting, updating, and deleting data, authenticating users, and handling errors.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the [Mobile Services quickstart](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-xamarin-ios-get-started.md) tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Mobile Services, you should consider first completing the [Mobile Services quickstart](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-xamarin-ios-get-started.md) tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Setup and Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Setup and Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: We assume that you have created a mobile service and a table.
trans-unit.target: We assume that you have created a mobile service and a table.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Create a table](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=298592).
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Create a table](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=298592).

trans-unit.source: In the code used in this topic, the table is named `TodoItem` and it will have the following columns: `Id`, `Text`, and `Complete`.
trans-unit.target: In the code used in this topic, the table is named `TodoItem` and it will have the following columns: `Id`, `Text`, and `Complete`.

trans-unit.source: The corresponding typed client-side .NET type is the following:
trans-unit.target: The corresponding typed client-side .NET type is the following:

trans-unit.source: Note that the [JsonPropertyAttribute](http://www.newtonsoft.com/json/help/html/Properties_T_Newtonsoft_Json_JsonPropertyAttribute.htm) is used to define the mapping between the PropertyName mapping between the client type and the table.
trans-unit.target: Note that the [JsonPropertyAttribute](http://www.newtonsoft.com/json/help/html/Properties_T_Newtonsoft_Json_JsonPropertyAttribute.htm) is used to define the mapping between the PropertyName mapping between the client type and the table.

trans-unit.source: When dynamic schema is enabled in a JavaScript backend mobile service, Azure Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the object in insert or update requests.
trans-unit.target: When dynamic schema is enabled in a JavaScript backend mobile service, Azure Mobile Services automatically generates new columns based on the object in insert or update requests.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Dynamic schema](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=296271).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Dynamic schema](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=296271).

trans-unit.source: In a .NET backend mobile service, the table is defined in the data model of the project.
trans-unit.target: In a .NET backend mobile service, the table is defined in the data model of the project.

trans-unit.source: How to: Create the Mobile Services client
trans-unit.target: How to: Create the Mobile Services client

trans-unit.source: The following code creates the `MobileServiceClient` object that is used to access your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates the `MobileServiceClient` object that is used to access your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the code above, replace `AppUrl` and `AppKey` with the mobile service URL and application key, in that order.
trans-unit.target: In the code above, replace `AppUrl` and `AppKey` with the mobile service URL and application key, in that order.

trans-unit.source: Both of these are available on the Azure classic portal, by selecting your mobile service and then clicking on "Dashboard".
trans-unit.target: Both of these are available on the Azure classic portal, by selecting your mobile service and then clicking on "Dashboard".

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT]The application key is intended to filter-out random request against your mobile service, and it is distributed with the application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT]The application key is intended to filter-out random request against your mobile service, and it is distributed with the application.

trans-unit.source: Because this key is not encrypted, it cannot be considered secure.
trans-unit.target: Because this key is not encrypted, it cannot be considered secure.

trans-unit.source: To truly secure your mobile service data, you must instead authenticate users before allowing access.
trans-unit.target: To truly secure your mobile service data, you must instead authenticate users before allowing access.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to: Authenticate users](#authentication).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to: Authenticate users](#authentication).

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a table reference
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a table reference

trans-unit.source: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the Mobile Services table calls functions on the `MobileServiceTable` object.
trans-unit.target: All of the code that accesses or modifies data in the Mobile Services table calls functions on the `MobileServiceTable` object.

trans-unit.source: You get a reference to the table by calling the [GetTable](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554275.aspx) method on an instance of the `MobileServiceClient`, as follows:
trans-unit.target: You get a reference to the table by calling the [GetTable](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554275.aspx) method on an instance of the `MobileServiceClient`, as follows:

trans-unit.target: This is the typed serialization model; see the discussion of the [untyped serialization model](#untyped) below.

trans-unit.source: How to: Query data from a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Query data from a mobile service

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to issue queries to the mobile service, which includes the following functionality:
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to issue queries to the mobile service, which includes the following functionality:

trans-unit.source: [Filter returned data]
trans-unit.target: [Filter returned data]

trans-unit.source: [Sort returned data]
trans-unit.target: [Sort returned data]

trans-unit.source: [Return data in pages]
trans-unit.target: [Return data in pages]

trans-unit.target: [Select specific columns]

trans-unit.source: [Look up data by ID]
trans-unit.target: [Look up data by ID]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] A server-driven page size is enforced to prevent all rows from being returned.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] A server-driven page size is enforced to prevent all rows from being returned.

trans-unit.source: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.
trans-unit.target: This keeps default requests for large data sets from negatively impacting the service.

trans-unit.source: To return more than 50 rows, use the `Take` method, as described in [Return data in pages].
trans-unit.target: To return more than 50 rows, use the `Take` method, as described in [Return data in pages].

trans-unit.source: How to: Filter returned data
trans-unit.target: How to: Filter returned data

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a `Where` clause in a query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to filter data by including a `Where` clause in a query.

trans-unit.source: It returns all items from `todoTable` whose `Complete` property is equal to `false`.
trans-unit.target: It returns all items from `todoTable` whose `Complete` property is equal to `false`.

trans-unit.source: The `Where` function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.
trans-unit.target: The `Where` function applies a row filtering predicate to the query against the table.

trans-unit.source: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or [Fiddler].
trans-unit.target: You can view the URI of the request sent to the mobile service by using message inspection software, such as browser developer tools or [Fiddler].

trans-unit.source: If you look at the request URI below, notice that we are modifying the query string itself:
trans-unit.target: If you look at the request URI below, notice that we are modifying the query string itself:

trans-unit.source: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:
trans-unit.target: This request would normally be translated roughly into the following SQL query on the server side:

trans-unit.target: The function which is passed to the `Where` method can have an arbitrary number of conditions.

trans-unit.source: For example, the line below:
trans-unit.target: For example, the line below:

trans-unit.source: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as
trans-unit.target: Would be roughly translated (for the same request shown before) as

trans-unit.source: The `where` statement above will find items with `Complete` status set to false with non-null `Text`.
trans-unit.target: The `where` statement above will find items with `Complete` status set to false with non-null `Text`.

trans-unit.source: We also could have written that in multiple lines instead:
trans-unit.target: We also could have written that in multiple lines instead:

trans-unit.source: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.
trans-unit.target: The two methods are equivalent and may be used interchangeably.

trans-unit.source: The former option -- of concatenating multiple predicates in one query -- is more compact and recommended.
trans-unit.target: The former option -- of concatenating multiple predicates in one query -- is more compact and recommended.

trans-unit.source: The `where` clause supports operations that be translated into the Mobile Services OData subset. This includ
trans-unit.target: The `where` clause supports operations that be translated into the Mobile Services OData subset. This includ

trans-unit.source: es relational operators (==, !=, <, <=, >, >=), arithmetic operators (+, -, /, *, %), number precision (Math.Floor, Math.Ceiling), string functions (Length, Substring, Replace, IndexOf, StartsWith, EndsWith), date properties (Year, Month, Day, Hour, Minute, Second), access properties of an object, and expressions combining all of these.
trans-unit.target: es relational operators (==, !=, <, <=, >, >=), arithmetic operators (+, -, /, *, %), number precision (Math.Floor, Math.Ceiling), string functions (Length, Substring, Replace, IndexOf, StartsWith, EndsWith), date properties (Year, Month, Day, Hour, Minute, Second), access properties of an object, and expressions combining all of these.

trans-unit.source: How to: Sort returned data
trans-unit.target: How to: Sort returned data

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an `OrderBy` or `OrderByDescending` function in the query.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to sort data by including an `OrderBy` or `OrderByDescending` function in the query.

trans-unit.source: It returns items from `todoTable` sorted ascending by the `Text` field.
trans-unit.target: It returns items from `todoTable` sorted ascending by the `Text` field.

trans-unit.source: How to: Return data in pages
trans-unit.target: How to: Return data in pages

trans-unit.source: By default, the server returns only the first 50 rows.
trans-unit.target: By default, the server returns only the first 50 rows.

trans-unit.source: You can increase the number of returned rows by calling the [Take] method.
trans-unit.target: You can increase the number of returned rows by calling the [Take] method.

trans-unit.source: Use `Take` along with the [Skip] method to request a specific "page" of the total dataset returned by the query.
trans-unit.target: Use `Take` along with the [Skip] method to request a specific "page" of the total dataset returned by the query.

trans-unit.source: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.
trans-unit.target: The following query, when executed, returns the top three items in the table.

trans-unit.source: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.
trans-unit.target: The following revised query skips the first three results and returns the next three after that.

trans-unit.source: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.
trans-unit.target: This is effectively the second "page" of data, where the page size is three items.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the [IncludeTotalCount] method to ensure that the query will get the total count for all the records that would have been returned, ignoring any take paging/limit clause specified:
trans-unit.target: You can also use the [IncludeTotalCount] method to ensure that the query will get the total count for all the records that would have been returned, ignoring any take paging/limit clause specified:

trans-unit.source: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the `Take` and `Skip` methods.
trans-unit.target: This is a simplified scenario of passing hard-coded paging values to the `Take` and `Skip` methods.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world app, you can use queries similar to the above with a pager control or comparable UI to let users navigate to previous and next pages.

trans-unit.source: Paging considerations for a .NET backend mobile service
trans-unit.target: Paging considerations for a .NET backend mobile service

trans-unit.source: To override the 50 row limit in a .NET backend mobile service, you must also apply the [EnableQueryAttribute](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.web.http.odata.enablequeryattribute.aspx) to the public GET method and specify the paging behavior.
trans-unit.target: To override the 50 row limit in a .NET backend mobile service, you must also apply the [EnableQueryAttribute](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.web.http.odata.enablequeryattribute.aspx) to the public GET method and specify the paging behavior.

trans-unit.source: When applied to the method, the following sets the maximum returned rows to 1000:
trans-unit.target: When applied to the method, the following sets the maximum returned rows to 1000:

trans-unit.target: How to: Select specific columns

trans-unit.source: How to: Look up data by ID
trans-unit.target: How to: Look up data by ID

trans-unit.source: The `LookupAsync` function can be used to look up objects from the database with a particular ID.
trans-unit.target: The `LookupAsync` function can be used to look up objects from the database with a particular ID.

trans-unit.source: How to: Insert data into a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Insert data into a mobile service

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to perform insert, lookup, delete, or update operations on a type, then you need to create a member called **Id**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to perform insert, lookup, delete, or update operations on a type, then you need to create a member called **Id**.

trans-unit.source: This is why the example class **TodoItem** has a member of name **Id**.
trans-unit.target: This is why the example class **TodoItem** has a member of name **Id**.

trans-unit.source: A valid id value must always be present in update and delete operations.
trans-unit.target: A valid id value must always be present in update and delete operations.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to insert new rows into a table.

trans-unit.source: The parameter contains the data to be inserted as a .NET object.
trans-unit.target: The parameter contains the data to be inserted as a .NET object.

trans-unit.source: If a unique custom ID value is not included in the `todoItem` passed to the `todoTable.InsertAsync` call, a value for ID is generated by the server and is set in the `todoItem` object returned to the client.
trans-unit.target: If a unique custom ID value is not included in the `todoItem` passed to the `todoTable.InsertAsync` call, a value for ID is generated by the server and is set in the `todoItem` object returned to the client.

trans-unit.source: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example using an email address as a unique string id.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example using an email address as a unique string id.

trans-unit.source: Working with ID values
trans-unit.target: Working with ID values

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's **id** column.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's **id** column.

trans-unit.source: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.
trans-unit.target: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.

trans-unit.source: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.
trans-unit.target: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.

trans-unit.source: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.
trans-unit.target: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.

trans-unit.source: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.
trans-unit.target: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.

trans-unit.source: When a string ID value is not set on an inserted record, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.
trans-unit.target: When a string ID value is not set on an inserted record, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.

trans-unit.source: You can use the `Guid.NewGuid()` method To generate your own ID values, either on the client or in a .NET mobile backend service.
trans-unit.target: You can use the `Guid.NewGuid()` method To generate your own ID values, either on the client or in a .NET mobile backend service.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about generating GUIDs in a JavaScript backend mobile service, see [How to: Generate unique ID values](mobile-services-how-to-use-server-scripts.md#generate-guids).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about generating GUIDs in a JavaScript backend mobile service, see [How to: Generate unique ID values](mobile-services-how-to-use-server-scripts.md#generate-guids).

trans-unit.source: You can also use integer IDs for your tables.
trans-unit.target: You can also use integer IDs for your tables.

trans-unit.source: To use an integer ID, you must create your table with the `mobile table create` command using the `--integerId` option.
trans-unit.target: To use an integer ID, you must create your table with the `mobile table create` command using the `--integerId` option.

trans-unit.source: This command is used with the Command-line Interface (CLI) for Azure.
trans-unit.target: This command is used with the Command-line Interface (CLI) for Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using the CLI, see [CLI to manage Mobile Services tables](../virtual-machines-command-line-tools.md#Mobile_Tables).
trans-unit.target: For more information on using the CLI, see [CLI to manage Mobile Services tables](../virtual-machines-command-line-tools.md#Mobile_Tables).

trans-unit.source: How to: Modify data in a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Modify data in a mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to update an existing instance with the same ID with new information.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to update an existing instance with the same ID with new information.

trans-unit.source: The parameter contains the data to be updated as a .NET object.
trans-unit.target: The parameter contains the data to be updated as a .NET object.

trans-unit.source: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.
trans-unit.target: To insert untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.

trans-unit.source: Note that when making an update, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to update.
trans-unit.target: Note that when making an update, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to update.

trans-unit.source: The ID can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.
trans-unit.target: The ID can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to update an item without providing the "Id" value, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to update, so the Mobile Services SDK will throw an `ArgumentException`.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to update an item without providing the "Id" value, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to update, so the Mobile Services SDK will throw an `ArgumentException`.

trans-unit.source: How to: Delete data in a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to: Delete data in a mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to delete an existing instance.
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to delete an existing instance.

trans-unit.source: The instance is identified by the "Id" field set on the `todoItem`.
trans-unit.target: The instance is identified by the "Id" field set on the `todoItem`.

trans-unit.source: To delete untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.
trans-unit.target: To delete untyped data, you may take advantage of Json.NET like so.

trans-unit.source: Note that when making a delete request, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to delete.
trans-unit.target: Note that when making a delete request, an ID must be specified, as that is how the mobile service identifies which instance to delete.

trans-unit.source: A delete request needs only the ID; other properties are not passed to the service, and if any are passed, they are ignored at the service.
trans-unit.target: A delete request needs only the ID; other properties are not passed to the service, and if any are passed, they are ignored at the service.

trans-unit.source: The result of a `DeleteAsync` call is usually `null` as well.
trans-unit.target: The result of a `DeleteAsync` call is usually `null` as well.

trans-unit.source: The ID to pass in can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.
trans-unit.target: The ID to pass in can be obtained from the result of the `InsertAsync` call.

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to delete an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to delete, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to delete an item without the "Id" field already set, there is no way for the service to tell which instance to delete, so you will get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if you attempt to delete an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if you attempt to delete an untyped item without the "Id" field already set, you will again get back a `MobileServiceInvalidOperationException` from the service.

trans-unit.source: How to: Call a custom API
trans-unit.target: How to: Call a custom API

trans-unit.source: A custom API enables you to define custom endpoints that expose server functionality that does not map to an insert, update, delete, or read operation.
trans-unit.target: A custom API enables you to define custom endpoints that expose server functionality that does not map to an insert, update, delete, or read operation.

trans-unit.source: By using a custom API, you can have more control over messaging, including reading and setting HTTP message headers and defining a message body format other than JSON.
trans-unit.target: By using a custom API, you can have more control over messaging, including reading and setting HTTP message headers and defining a message body format other than JSON.

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to create a custom API in your mobile service, see [How to: define a custom API endpoint](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-define-custom-api.md).
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to create a custom API in your mobile service, see [How to: define a custom API endpoint](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-define-custom-api.md).

trans-unit.source: You call a custom API by calling one of the [InvokeApiAsync] method overloads on the client.
trans-unit.target: You call a custom API by calling one of the [InvokeApiAsync] method overloads on the client.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following line of code sends a POST request to the **completeAll** API on the mobile service:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following line of code sends a POST request to the **completeAll** API on the mobile service:

trans-unit.source: Note that this a typed method call, which requires that the **MarkAllResult** return type be defined.
trans-unit.target: Note that this a typed method call, which requires that the **MarkAllResult** return type be defined.

trans-unit.source: Both typed and untyped methods are supported.
trans-unit.target: Both typed and untyped methods are supported.

trans-unit.source: This is an almost trivial example as it is typed, sends no payload, has no query parameters, and doesn't change the request headers.
trans-unit.target: This is an almost trivial example as it is typed, sends no payload, has no query parameters, and doesn't change the request headers.

trans-unit.source: For more realistic examples and a more a complete discussion of [InvokeApiAsync], see [Custom API in Azure Mobile Services Client SDKs].
trans-unit.target: For more realistic examples and a more a complete discussion of [InvokeApiAsync], see [Custom API in Azure Mobile Services Client SDKs].

trans-unit.source: How to: Register for push notifications
trans-unit.target: How to: Register for push notifications

trans-unit.source: The Mobile Services client enables you to register for push notifications with Azure Notification Hubs.
trans-unit.target: The Mobile Services client enables you to register for push notifications with Azure Notification Hubs.

trans-unit.source: When registering, you obtain a handle that you obtain from the platform-specific Push Notification Service (PNS).
trans-unit.target: When registering, you obtain a handle that you obtain from the platform-specific Push Notification Service (PNS).

trans-unit.source: You then provide this value along with any tags when you create the registration.
trans-unit.target: You then provide this value along with any tags when you create the registration.

trans-unit.source: The following code registers your Windows app for push notifications with the Windows Notification Service (WNS):
trans-unit.target: The following code registers your Windows app for push notifications with the Windows Notification Service (WNS):

trans-unit.source: Note that in this example, two tags are included with the registration.
trans-unit.target: Note that in this example, two tags are included with the registration.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Windows apps, see [Add push notifications to your app](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-push.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Windows apps, see [Add push notifications to your app](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-push.md).

trans-unit.source: Xamarin apps require some additional code to be able to register a Xamarin app running on iOS or Android app with the Apple Push Notification Service (APNS) and Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) services, respectively.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin apps require some additional code to be able to register a Xamarin app running on iOS or Android app with the Apple Push Notification Service (APNS) and Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) services, respectively.

trans-unit.source: For more information see **Add push notifications to your app** ([Xamarin.iOS](partner-xamarin-mobile-services-ios-get-started-push.md#add-push) | [Xamarin.Android](partner-xamarin-mobile-services-android-get-started-push.md#add-push)).
trans-unit.target: For more information see **Add push notifications to your app** ([Xamarin.iOS](partner-xamarin-mobile-services-ios-get-started-push.md#add-push) | [Xamarin.Android](partner-xamarin-mobile-services-android-get-started-push.md#add-push)).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]When you need to send notifications to specific registered users, it is important to require authentication before registration, and then verify that the user is authorized to register with a specific tag.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]When you need to send notifications to specific registered users, it is important to require authentication before registration, and then verify that the user is authorized to register with a specific tag.

trans-unit.source: For example, you must check to make sure a user doesn't register with a tag that is someone else's user ID.
trans-unit.target: For example, you must check to make sure a user doesn't register with a tag that is someone else's user ID.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Send push notifications to authenticated users](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-store-dotnet-push-notifications-app-users.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Send push notifications to authenticated users](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-store-dotnet-push-notifications-app-users.md).

trans-unit.source: How to: Use periodic notifications in a Windows app
trans-unit.target: How to: Use periodic notifications in a Windows app

trans-unit.source: Windows supports period notifications (pull notifications) to update live tiles.
trans-unit.target: Windows supports period notifications (pull notifications) to update live tiles.

trans-unit.source: With periodic notifications enabled, Windows will periodically access a custom API endpoint to update the app tile on the start menu.
trans-unit.target: With periodic notifications enabled, Windows will periodically access a custom API endpoint to update the app tile on the start menu.

trans-unit.source: To use periodic notifications, you must [define a custom API](mobile-services-javascript-backend-define-custom-api.md) that returns XML data in a tile-specific format.
trans-unit.target: To use periodic notifications, you must [define a custom API](mobile-services-javascript-backend-define-custom-api.md) that returns XML data in a tile-specific format.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Periodic notifications](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh761461.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Periodic notifications](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh761461.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The following example turns on period notifications to request tile template data from a *tiles* custom endpoint:
trans-unit.target: The following example turns on period notifications to request tile template data from a *tiles* custom endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Select a [PeriodicUpdateRecurrance](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.notifications.periodicupdaterecurrence.aspx) value that best matches the update frequency of your data.
trans-unit.target: Select a [PeriodicUpdateRecurrance](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.notifications.periodicupdaterecurrence.aspx) value that best matches the update frequency of your data.

trans-unit.source: How to: Use optimistic concurrency
trans-unit.target: How to: Use optimistic concurrency

trans-unit.source: Two or more clients may write changes to the same item, at the same time, in some scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Two or more clients may write changes to the same item, at the same time, in some scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Without any conflict detection, the last write would overwrite any previous updates even if this was not the desired result.
trans-unit.target: Without any conflict detection, the last write would overwrite any previous updates even if this was not the desired result.

trans-unit.source: Optimistic Concurrency Control assumes that each transaction can commit and therefore does not use any resource locking.
trans-unit.target: Optimistic Concurrency Control assumes that each transaction can commit and therefore does not use any resource locking.

trans-unit.source: Before committing a transaction, optimistic concurrency control verifies that no other transaction has modified the data.
trans-unit.target: Before committing a transaction, optimistic concurrency control verifies that no other transaction has modified the data.

trans-unit.source: If the data has been modified, the committing transaction is rolled back.
trans-unit.target: If the data has been modified, the committing transaction is rolled back.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports optimistic concurrency control by tracking changes to each item using the `__version` system property column that is defined for each table created by Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports optimistic concurrency control by tracking changes to each item using the `__version` system property column that is defined for each table created by Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Each time a record is updated, Mobile Services sets the `__version` property for that record to a new value.
trans-unit.target: Each time a record is updated, Mobile Services sets the `__version` property for that record to a new value.

trans-unit.source: During each update request, the `__version` property of the record included with the request is compared to the same property for the record on the server.
trans-unit.target: During each update request, the `__version` property of the record included with the request is compared to the same property for the record on the server.

trans-unit.source: If the version passed with the request does not match the server, then the Mobile Services .NET client library throws a `MobileServicePreconditionFailedException<T>`.
trans-unit.target: If the version passed with the request does not match the server, then the Mobile Services .NET client library throws a `MobileServicePreconditionFailedException<T>`.

trans-unit.source: The type included with the exception is the record from the server containing the server's version of the record.
trans-unit.target: The type included with the exception is the record from the server containing the server's version of the record.

trans-unit.source: The application can then use this information to decide whether to execute the update request again with the correct `__version` value from the server to commit changes.
trans-unit.target: The application can then use this information to decide whether to execute the update request again with the correct `__version` value from the server to commit changes.

trans-unit.source: To enable optimistic concurrency the application defines a column on the table class for the `__version` system property.
trans-unit.target: To enable optimistic concurrency the application defines a column on the table class for the `__version` system property.

trans-unit.source: The following definition provides an example.
trans-unit.target: The following definition provides an example.

trans-unit.source: Applications using untyped tables enable optimistic concurrency by setting the `Version` flag on the `SystemProperties` of the table as follows.
trans-unit.target: Applications using untyped tables enable optimistic concurrency by setting the `Version` flag on the `SystemProperties` of the table as follows.

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to resolve a write conflict once detected.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to resolve a write conflict once detected.

trans-unit.source: The correct `__version` value must be included in the `UpdateAsync()` call to commit a resolution.
trans-unit.target: The correct `__version` value must be included in the `UpdateAsync()` call to commit a resolution.

trans-unit.source: For a more complete example of using optimistic concurrency for Mobile Services, see the [Optimistic Concurrency Tutorial].
trans-unit.target: For a more complete example of using optimistic concurrency for Mobile Services, see the [Optimistic Concurrency Tutorial].

trans-unit.source: How to: Bind mobile service data to a Windows user interface
trans-unit.target: How to: Bind mobile service data to a Windows user interface

trans-unit.source: This section shows how to display returned data objects using UI elements in a Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This section shows how to display returned data objects using UI elements in a Windows app.

trans-unit.source: To query incomplete items in `todoTable` and display it in a very simple list, you can run the following example code to bind the source of the list with a query.
trans-unit.target: To query incomplete items in `todoTable` and display it in a very simple list, you can run the following example code to bind the source of the list with a query.

trans-unit.source: Using `MobileServiceCollection` creates a mobile services-aware binding collection.
trans-unit.target: Using `MobileServiceCollection` creates a mobile services-aware binding collection.

trans-unit.source: Some controls in the managed runtime support an interface called [ISupportIncrementalLoading](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh701916).
trans-unit.target: Some controls in the managed runtime support an interface called [ISupportIncrementalLoading](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh701916).

trans-unit.source: This interface allows controls to request extra data when the user scrolls.
trans-unit.target: This interface allows controls to request extra data when the user scrolls.

trans-unit.source: There is built-in support for this interface for universal Windows 8.1 apps via `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection`, which automatically handles the calls from the controls.
trans-unit.target: There is built-in support for this interface for universal Windows 8.1 apps via `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection`, which automatically handles the calls from the controls.

trans-unit.source: To use `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection` in Windows apps, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To use `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection` in Windows apps, do the following:

trans-unit.source: To use the new collection on Windows Phone 8 and "Silverlight" apps, use the `ToCollection` extension methods on `IMobileServiceTableQuery<T>` and `IMobileServiceTable<T>`.
trans-unit.target: To use the new collection on Windows Phone 8 and "Silverlight" apps, use the `ToCollection` extension methods on `IMobileServiceTableQuery<T>` and `IMobileServiceTable<T>`.

trans-unit.source: To actually load data, call `LoadMoreItemsAsync()`.
trans-unit.target: To actually load data, call `LoadMoreItemsAsync()`.

trans-unit.source: When you use the collection created by calling `ToCollectionAsync` or `ToCollection`, you get a collection which can be bound to UI controls.
trans-unit.target: When you use the collection created by calling `ToCollectionAsync` or `ToCollection`, you get a collection which can be bound to UI controls.

trans-unit.source: This collection is paging-aware, i.e., a control can ask the collection to "load more items", and the collection will do it for the control.
trans-unit.target: This collection is paging-aware, i.e., a control can ask the collection to "load more items", and the collection will do it for the control.

trans-unit.source: At that point there is no user code involved, the control will start the flow.
trans-unit.target: At that point there is no user code involved, the control will start the flow.

trans-unit.source: However, since the collection is loading data from the network, it's expected that some times this loading will fail.
trans-unit.target: However, since the collection is loading data from the network, it's expected that some times this loading will fail.

trans-unit.source: To handle such failures, you may override the `OnException` method on `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection` to handle exceptions resulting from calls to `LoadMoreItemsAsync` performed by controls.
trans-unit.target: To handle such failures, you may override the `OnException` method on `MobileServiceIncrementalLoadingCollection` to handle exceptions resulting from calls to `LoadMoreItemsAsync` performed by controls.

trans-unit.source: Finally, imagine that your table has many fields, but you only want to display some of them in your control.
trans-unit.target: Finally, imagine that your table has many fields, but you only want to display some of them in your control.

trans-unit.source: You may use the guidance in the section "[Select specific columns](#selecting)" above to select specific columns to display in the UI.
trans-unit.target: You may use the guidance in the section "[Select specific columns](#selecting)" above to select specific columns to display in the UI.

trans-unit.source: How to: Authenticate users
trans-unit.target: How to: Authenticate users

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, Twitter, and Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports authenticating and authorizing app users using a variety of external identity providers: Facebook, Google, Microsoft Account, Twitter, and Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: You can set permissions on tables to restrict access for specific operations to only authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the identity of authenticated users to implement authorization rules in server scripts.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the tutorial [Add authentication to your app].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the tutorial [Add authentication to your app].

trans-unit.source: Two authentication flows are supported: a _server flow_ and a _client flow_.
trans-unit.target: Two authentication flows are supported: a _server flow_ and a _client flow_.

trans-unit.source: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.
trans-unit.target: The server flow provides the simplest authentication experience, as it relies on the provider's web authentication interface.

trans-unit.source: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.
trans-unit.target: The client flow allows for deeper integration with device-specific capabilities as it relies on provider-specific device-specific SDKs.

trans-unit.source: Server flow
trans-unit.target: Server flow

trans-unit.source: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows apps,
trans-unit.target: To have Mobile Services manage the authentication process in your Windows apps,

trans-unit.source: you must register your app with your identity provider.
trans-unit.target: you must register your app with your identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.
trans-unit.target: Then in your mobile service, you need to configure the application ID and secret provided by your provider.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the tutorial [Add authentication to your app].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the tutorial [Add authentication to your app].

trans-unit.source: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.
trans-unit.target: Once you have registered your identity provider, simply call the [LoginAsync method] with the [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] value of your provider.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code initiates a server flow sign-in by using Facebook.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code initiates a server flow sign-in by using Facebook.

trans-unit.source: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value of [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] above to the value for your provider.
trans-unit.target: If you are using an identity provider other than Facebook, change the value of [MobileServiceAuthenticationProvider] above to the value for your provider.

trans-unit.source: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the sign-in page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful sign-on with the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In this case, Mobile Services manages the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow by displaying the sign-in page of the selected provider and generating a Mobile Services authentication token after successful sign-on with the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The [LoginAsync method] returns a [MobileServiceUser], which provides both the [userId] of the authenticated user and the [MobileServiceAuthenticationToken], as a JSON web token (JWT).
trans-unit.target: The [LoginAsync method] returns a [MobileServiceUser], which provides both the [userId] of the authenticated user and the [MobileServiceAuthenticationToken], as a JSON web token (JWT).

trans-unit.source: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.
trans-unit.target: This token can be cached and re-used until it expires.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Caching the authentication token].

trans-unit.source: Client flow
trans-unit.target: Client flow

trans-unit.source: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Your app can also independently contact the identity provider and then provide the returned token to Mobile Services for authentication.

trans-unit.source: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: This client flow enables you to provide a single sign-in experience for users or to retrieve additional user data from the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Single sign-in using a token from Facebook or Google
trans-unit.target: Single sign-in using a token from Facebook or Google

trans-unit.source: In the most simplified form, you can use the client flow as shown in this snippet for Facebook or Google.
trans-unit.target: In the most simplified form, you can use the client flow as shown in this snippet for Facebook or Google.

trans-unit.source: Single sign-in using Microsoft Account with the Live SDK
trans-unit.target: Single sign-in using Microsoft Account with the Live SDK

trans-unit.source: To be able to authenticate users, you must register your app at the Microsoft account Developer Center.
trans-unit.target: To be able to authenticate users, you must register your app at the Microsoft account Developer Center.

trans-unit.source: You must then connect this registration with your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: You must then connect this registration with your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Complete the steps in [Register your app to use a Microsoft account login](mobile-services-how-to-register-microsoft-authentication.md) to create a Microsoft account registration and connect it to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Complete the steps in [Register your app to use a Microsoft account login](mobile-services-how-to-register-microsoft-authentication.md) to create a Microsoft account registration and connect it to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If you have both Windows Store and Windows Phone 8/Silverlight versions of your app, register the Windows Store version first.
trans-unit.target: If you have both Windows Store and Windows Phone 8/Silverlight versions of your app, register the Windows Store version first.

trans-unit.source: The following code authenticates using Live SDK and uses the returned token to sign-in to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The following code authenticates using Live SDK and uses the returned token to sign-in to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Caching the authentication token
trans-unit.target: Caching the authentication token

trans-unit.source: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, the call to the login method can be avoided after the first time the user authenticates.

trans-unit.source: You can use [PasswordVault] for Windows Store apps to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time you check whether you already have the user identity in our cache.
trans-unit.target: You can use [PasswordVault] for Windows Store apps to cache the current user identity the first time they log in and every subsequent time you check whether you already have the user identity in our cache.

trans-unit.source: When the cache is empty, you still need to send the user through the login process.
trans-unit.target: When the cache is empty, you still need to send the user through the login process.

trans-unit.source: For Windows Phone apps, you may encrypt and cache data using the [ProtectedData] class and store sensitive information in isolated storage.
trans-unit.target: For Windows Phone apps, you may encrypt and cache data using the [ProtectedData] class and store sensitive information in isolated storage.

trans-unit.source: How to: Handle errors
trans-unit.target: How to: Handle errors

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to encounter, validate, and work around errors in Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.
trans-unit.target: As an example, server scripts are registered in a mobile service and can be used to perform a wide range of operations on data being inserted and updated, including validation and data modification.

trans-unit.source: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:
trans-unit.target: Imagine defining and registering a server script that validate and modify data, like so:

trans-unit.source: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.
trans-unit.target: This server-side script validates the length of string data sent to the mobile service and rejects strings that are too long, in this case longer than 10 characters.

trans-unit.source: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your .NET app to be able to handle error responses from validation.
trans-unit.target: Now that the mobile service is validating data and sending error responses on the server-side, you can update your .NET app to be able to handle error responses from validation.

trans-unit.source: How to: Work with untyped data
trans-unit.target: How to: Work with untyped data

trans-unit.source: The .NET client is designed for strongly typed scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The .NET client is designed for strongly typed scenarios.

trans-unit.source: However, sometimes, a more loosely typed experience is convenient; for example, this could be when dealing with objects with open schema.
trans-unit.target: However, sometimes, a more loosely typed experience is convenient; for example, this could be when dealing with objects with open schema.

trans-unit.source: That scenario is enabled as follows.
trans-unit.target: That scenario is enabled as follows.

trans-unit.source: In queries, you forego LINQ and use the wire format.
trans-unit.target: In queries, you forego LINQ and use the wire format.

trans-unit.source: You get back JSON values that you can use like a property bag.
trans-unit.target: You get back JSON values that you can use like a property bag.

trans-unit.source: For more information on JToken and Json.NET, see [Json.NET](http://json.codeplex.com/)
trans-unit.target: For more information on JToken and Json.NET, see [Json.NET](http://json.codeplex.com/)

trans-unit.source: How to: Design unit tests
trans-unit.target: How to: Design unit tests

trans-unit.source: The value returned by `MobileServiceClient.GetTable` and the queries are interfaces.
trans-unit.target: The value returned by `MobileServiceClient.GetTable` and the queries are interfaces.

trans-unit.source: That makes them easily "mockable" for testing purposes, so you could create a `MyMockTable : IMobileServiceTable<TodoItem>` that implements your testing logic.
trans-unit.target: That makes them easily "mockable" for testing purposes, so you could create a `MyMockTable : IMobileServiceTable<TodoItem>` that implements your testing logic.

trans-unit.source: How to: Customize the client
trans-unit.target: How to: Customize the client

trans-unit.source: This section shows ways in which you can customize the request headers and customize the serialization of JSON objects in the response.
trans-unit.target: This section shows ways in which you can customize the request headers and customize the serialization of JSON objects in the response.

trans-unit.source: How to: Customize request headers
trans-unit.target: How to: Customize request headers

trans-unit.source: To support your specific app scenario, you might need to customize communication with the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: To support your specific app scenario, you might need to customize communication with the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may want to add a custom header to every outgoing request or even change responses status codes.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may want to add a custom header to every outgoing request or even change responses status codes.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by providing a custom DelegatingHandler, as in the following example:
trans-unit.target: You can do this by providing a custom DelegatingHandler, as in the following example:

trans-unit.source: This code adds a new **x-my-header** header in the request and arbitrarily sets the response code to unavailable.
trans-unit.target: This code adds a new **x-my-header** header in the request and arbitrarily sets the response code to unavailable.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world scenario, you would set the response status code based on some custom logic required by your app.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world scenario, you would set the response status code based on some custom logic required by your app.

trans-unit.source: How to: Customize serialization
trans-unit.target: How to: Customize serialization

trans-unit.source: The Mobile Services client library uses Json.NET to convert a JSON response into .NET objects on the client.
trans-unit.target: The Mobile Services client library uses Json.NET to convert a JSON response into .NET objects on the client.

trans-unit.source: You can configure the behavior of this serialization between .NET types and JSON in the messages.
trans-unit.target: You can configure the behavior of this serialization between .NET types and JSON in the messages.

trans-unit.source: The [MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.mobileservices.mobileserviceclient.aspx) class exposes a `SerializerSettings` property of type [JsonSerializerSettings](http://james.newtonking.com/projects/json/help/?topic=html/T_Newtonsoft_Json_JsonSerializerSettings.htm)
trans-unit.target: The [MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.windowsazure.mobileservices.mobileserviceclient.aspx) class exposes a `SerializerSettings` property of type [JsonSerializerSettings](http://james.newtonking.com/projects/json/help/?topic=html/T_Newtonsoft_Json_JsonSerializerSettings.htm)

trans-unit.source: Using this property, you may set one of the many Json.NET properties, such as the following:
trans-unit.target: Using this property, you may set one of the many Json.NET properties, such as the following:

trans-unit.source: This property converts all properties to lower case during serialization.
trans-unit.target: This property converts all properties to lower case during serialization.
